items.title: Hiveclass, a platform for virtual PE classes for kids, raises $1.5M
items.author: Lauren Forristal
items.summary:
• Hiveclass is a New York-based edtech platform providing online P.E. classes for K-12 students, covering fitness, dance, yoga, and more.
• The platform aims to combat disengagement in physical education and the high costs of youth sports.
• Recently raised $1.5 million in seed funding to enhance product development, a teacher portal, and services for special needs students.
• Hiveclass markets to public schools instead of directly to parents, partnering with over 80 educational institutions and engaging more than 13,000 students.
• The company has generated over $2 million in revenue and aims for an additional $1 million soon, exploring further revenue streams.
• Led by Spring Mountain Capital, the funding round included various investors and brings total raised to over $3 million.

items.title: Coalition of US states to file lawsuit after Musk’s DOGE gains access to Americans’ personal data
items.author: Zack Whittaker
items.summary:
- A coalition of over a dozen U.S. states plans to file a lawsuit against Elon Musk's DOGE team for accessing sensitive federal payment systems containing American personal data.
- The coalition is led by 13 Democratic attorneys general, including those from California, Connecticut, Maine, Maryland, and New York, seeking to defend privacy rights and essential funding for communities.
- Musk’s DOGE has recently gained control of major U.S. agencies, raising concerns about national security due to Musk's business ties with China.

items.title: UK government demands Apple backdoor to encrypted cloud data: report
items.summary:
- The UK government secretly ordered Apple to create a backdoor for accessing users' encrypted iCloud data.
- The demand was made in January under the UK's Investigatory Powers Act 2016, requesting blanket access to all encrypted files.
- Apple may stop offering its encrypted cloud storage, Advanced Data Protection, to UK users due to this demand.

items.title: Composo helps enterprises monitor how well AI apps work
items.author: Sebastian Fox
items.summary:
- London-based startup [Composo](https://www.composo.ai/) helps enterprises evaluate the accuracy of large language model applications.
- Offers both no-code and API options, allowing non-developers to assess AI apps.
- Recently raised $2 million in pre-seed funding, working with clients like Accenture and Palantir.
- Plans to expand its engineering team and bolster R&D efforts.
- Focuses on reducing risks associated with unreliable AI in various industries including compliance, legal, healthcare, and security.

items.title: PowerSchool data breach affected 16,000 students in the UK
items.author: Carly Page
items.summary:
- U.S. edtech giant PowerSchool confirmed a data breach affecting 16,000 students in the UK in December 2024.
- The breach involved hackers accessing personal data via compromised customer support credentials.
- Affected data includes contact information, dates of birth, limited medical data, and related information.
- Four UK schools were specifically mentioned as impacted, though names were not disclosed.
- PowerSchool has not reported the breach to the Information Commissioner’s Office (ICO) in the UK yet.

items.title: UAE to invest billions to build AI data center in France
items.author: Romain Dillet
items.summary:
- UAE and France signed an agreement to invest €30 to €50 billion ($31 to 52 billion) for an AI data center in France.
- The data center will have a capacity of up to 1GW and is part of preparations for the AI Action Summit in Paris.
- France has identified 35 possible locations for new data centers and aims to attract foreign investments, especially in renewable energy.
- A consortium of French and Emirati investors, including the Emirati firm MGX, will support the project.
- The AI Action Summit will be attended by global leaders, discussing various investments and the environmental impact of AI.

items.title: Meta launches new program to improve speech and translation AI
items.author: Kyle Wiggers
items.summary: • Meta is launching a program in partnership with UNESCO to collect speech recordings and transcriptions for AI development. • The Language Technology Partner Program seeks collaborators for diverse languages, requiring over 10 hours of recordings and transcriptions. • Current partners include the government of Nunavut, focusing on underserved languages like Inuktut. • Meta is also releasing an open source machine translation benchmark to assess language models. • The initiatives are framed as philanthropic, but Meta aims to enhance its own AI capabilities for translation and speech recognition.

items.title: Meta is studying how humans and robots can collaborate on housework
items.author: Brian Heater
items.summary:
- Meta launched PARTNR, a program to study human-robot interaction focused on collaboration in domestic tasks like cleaning and cooking.
- Automated housework has been a longstanding aspiration, but only robot vacuums have gained traction in the market due to issues like cost and functionality.
- PARTNR includes 100,000 tasks for robots, with a dataset released for training AI models, also successfully tested with Boston Dynamics’ Spot robot.
- The initiative aims to reimagine robots as partners in households, facilitating research in human-robot collaboration.

items.title: Swiggy, 2024’s biggest tech listing, falls below its IPO price and 2022 valuation
items.author: Manish Singh
items.summary:
- Swiggy's stock dropped to ₹374.80 ($4.29), below its November IPO price of ₹390.
- The decrease in stock price resulted in a market cap of $9.75 billion.
- Swiggy's Instamart business reported a loss of market share despite store expansion and increased marketing.
- Competitor Zomato's Blinkit achieved double the gross order value of Instamart this quarter.
- Swiggy added 96 dark stores, totaling 705, but was outpaced by Blinkit's 216 stores for a total of 1,007.
- Swiggy's cash reserves are ₹82 billion ($936 million), less than Zomato's ₹190 billion ($2.2 billion).

items.title: India to launch new domain name for banks to fight digital fraud
items.summary:
- India’s central bank is introducing a new domain, “.bank.in”, for banks starting April 2025 to combat digital payment fraud.
- The Institute for Development and Research in Banking Technology (IDRBT) will be the exclusive registrar for this domain.
- A separate ‘fin.in’ domain will also be launched for non-bank financial institutions.
- RBI Governor Sanjay Malhotra emphasized the need for this initiative to combat increased cyber security threats and fraud in digital payments.
- The move addresses the rising incidents of fraud and aims to help users identify legitimate banking sites.

items.title: Sprinklr cuts 500 employees, citing underwhelming business performance
items.author: Jagmeet Singh
items.summary:
- Sprinklr has laid off about 500 employees (15% of its workforce) due to underwhelming business performance.
- This follows previous layoffs of 3% in May 2024 and 4% in 2023, totaling around 200 employees affected.
- The company will continue to hire in prioritized areas and emphasized a refocus on its strategic priorities, including AI development.

items.title: Carried interest repeal could stifle investments in startups, NVCA says
items.author: Marina Temkin
items.summary:
- President Trump requested Republican lawmakers to end tax breaks on carried interest.
- Carried interest tax break allows private equity managers to benefit from lower capital gains rates.
- Removal of this tax break could significantly impact the VC industry, according to NVCA President Bobby Franklin.
- Franklin expressed that carried interest supports high-risk investments in startups.
- Previous attempts to eliminate the loophole were not included in the 2017 Tax Cuts and Jobs Act.
- The 2017 modifications helped maintain venture investments in emerging technologies like AI and crypto.
- Majority of capital for emerging tech companies is still concentrated in New York and Silicon Valley.

items.title: OpenAI’s ex-CTO, Mira Murati, recruits co-founder John Schulman for new startup
items.summary:
- John Schulman, ex-co-founder of OpenAI, is joining Mira Murati’s new startup after leaving Anthropic.
- Schulman left Anthropic after five months, and his specific role in the new venture is unclear.
- Murati has also recruited other former OpenAI staff, including Christian Gibson from the supercomputing team.
- She was in talks to raise over $100 million for her startup as of October.

items.title: Orgs demand action to mitigate AI’s environmental harm
items.author: Kyle Wiggers
items.summary:
- Over 100 organizations published an [open letter](https://greenscreen.network/en/blog/within-bounds-limiting-ai-environmental-impact/) urging action against AI's environmental impact just before a major AI conference in Paris.
- The letter highlights evidence of AI systems increasing emissions and reliance on non-renewables, yet minimal action is taken.
- Demands include ensuring AI infrastructure is fossil fuel-free to combat increased electricity consumption tied to AI development, projected to double by 2026.
- The letter calls for transparency regarding AI's environmental impacts and responsible use of water and land resources by data centers.
- Vulnerable communities face the brunt of AI's impact amidst a U.S. trend favoring rapid growth, including support for coal energy for AI data centers.

items.title: Amazon doubles down on AI with a massive $100B spending plan for 2025
items.author: Charles Rollet
items.summary:
- Amazon plans to invest over $100 billion in AI capabilities for 2025, focusing on its AWS cloud division.
- CEO Andy Jassy indicated that the Q4 2024 capex of $26.3 billion is representative of annual spending for 2025, totaling approximately $105.2 billion.
- This marks an increase from the $75 billion capex expected in 2024.
- Jassy dismissed concerns about reduced AI costs impacting revenue, asserting that lower prices increase demand instead.
- Other tech giants like Meta and Microsoft also announced massive AI spending plans for the coming years, highlighting a trend in the industry.

items.title: Government agency removes spoon emoji from work platform amid protests
items.summary:
- The U.S. General Services Administration (GSA) removed the spoon emoji from its videoconferencing platform.
- The removal followed protests by workers who used the emoji to express dissent against the Trump administration's resignation offer titled "A Fork in the Road."
- Federal employees protested during a 600-person video conference and some changed their Slack statuses to feature the spoon emoji.

items.title: Early Meta Employee Sues for Sexual Harassment, Gender Discrimination
items.summary:
- Kelly Stonelake, a former Meta director, filed a lawsuit against the company in Washington for sexual harassment, gender discrimination, and retaliation.
- Stonelake claims she faced ongoing harassment and discrimination from 2009 until her layoff in January 2024, including incidents involving unwanted physical contact and coercion for promotions.
- Despite reporting harassment, Meta allegedly took no action, leading to ongoing mental health issues for Stonelake, who was on medical leave for PTSD when she was laid off.

items.title: OpenAI now reveals more of its o3-mini model’s thought process
items.author: Kyle Wiggers
items.summary:
- OpenAI updates the communication style of its o3-mini model to clarify its reasoning process in response to competitive pressure.
- Free and premium ChatGPT users will see an enhanced “chain of thought” feature detailing how the model formulates answers.
- The update aims to make the model's reasoning clearer and more accessible, particularly for non-English users, while still not disclosing the full thought process.

items.title: DOGE staffer steps down after racist posts emerge
Pour one out for Cruise and why autonomous vehicle test miles dropped 50%
items.summary:
- Cruise has been acquired by General Motors, leading to its dissolution as a robotaxi company.
- There will be a 50% workforce reduction, about 1,000 employees, as GM integrates Cruise into its operations.
- The California DMV reported a 50% drop in autonomous vehicle test miles, partially due to Cruise's closure.
- Cruise had plans to implement a sensor solution for safety issues related to a previous incident involving its robotaxi.
- Waymo is now appearing on the Uber app in Austin, marking a new phase in its service rollout.

items.title: Tinder will try AI-powered matching as the dating app continues to lose users
items.author: Sarah Perez
items.summary:
- Tinder will introduce AI-powered features aimed at improving user discovery and matching.
- The AI-curated recommendations are intended to provide more personalized matches and offer alternatives to the traditional swiping method.
- The company reported a decline in monthly active users (MAUs), which dropped 10% year over year in October, slightly improving to a 9% decline by December.
- In Q4, Tinder's revenue missed internal guidance at $476 million, below the forecast of $480-$485 million, despite an overall revenue of $860 million.
- New CEO Spencer Rascoff expressed optimism about AI's potential to drive growth similar to the shift from desktop to mobile in the past.

items.title: Snap CEO helps launch LA wildfire recovery program
items.author: Evan Spiegel, Miguel Santana
items.summary:
- Snap CEO Evan Spiegel and California Community Foundation CEO Miguel Santana are launching a recovery program for wildfire-affected residents in Altadena and Pacific Palisades.
- The program, named the [Department of Angels](https://www.deptofangels.org/about), is backed by $10 million in funding from Snap and the California Community Foundation.
- The initiative aims to empower local communities to manage their own recovery efforts post-wildfires, emphasizing grassroots involvement and independent project management support.

items.title: Tracking the EV battery factory construction boom across North America
items.summary:
- The onshoring of EV battery manufacturing surged from 4 factories in 2019 to 34 planned or operational in the U.S. today.
- The Inflation Reduction Act (IRA) signed by Biden accelerated this trend, despite Trump's recent freeze on funding.
- U.S. automakers and battery producers have pledged approximately $112 billion in investments to build domestic battery manufacturing capabilities before 2030.

items.title: Tesla Dojo: Elon Musk’s big plan to build an AI supercomputer, explained
items.summary:
- Elon Musk has been promoting Dojo, an AI supercomputer, as central to Tesla's AI ambitions since its inaugural mention in 2019.
- Dojo is integral for training Tesla's Full Self-Driving (FSD) neural networks, aiming for autonomous vehicle efficiency and launch plans for a ride-hail service by June 2025.
- Tesla focuses on a vision-only approach, collecting data using cameras to achieve autonomous driving, differing from competitors using multiple sensors.
- The supercomputer uses D1 chips optimized for AI workloads, manufactured by TSMC with 50 billion transistors, aiming to enhance computational efficiency.
- Musk indicated a transition towards Tesla-designed AI hardware to reduce dependency on Nvidia's increasingly costly GPUs, planning a 50/50 split in hardware sourcing in the upcoming years.

items.title: Google is adding digital watermarks to images edited with Magic Editor AI
items.author: Brian Heater
items.summary:
- Google announced digital watermarks will be added to images edited with generative AI using Magic Editor's Reimagine feature.
- Reimagine enables dramatic image edits, making it difficult to distinguish between digital photos and AI-generated images.
- Digital watermarking is seen as a solution for transparency in AI editing, ensuring users can identify AI-altered content.
- Google uses SynthID to embed watermarks without compromising original images, and it works with AI-generated text and videos.
- Users can find watermarks in image metadata via ‘About this Image’.

items.title: Snapchat+ Subscribers Can Now Create Custom AI-Generated Stickers
items.author: Aisha Malik
items.summary:
- Snapchat+ subscribers can now create custom AI-generated stickers that match their messages in chats.
- Subscribers can also send self-destructing Snaps through a new feature called "Snap Modes," which allows disappearing Snaps if not viewed within a set time.
- Snapchat plans to enhance its subscription service, which currently has 14 million subscribers, contributing to significant revenue growth for the company.

items.title: Ford goes protectionist as EV losses top $5B
items.author: Sean O'Kane
items.summary:
- Ford CEO Jim Farley questions Trump's selective tariffs, emphasizing the need for a comprehensive tariff policy.
- Ford lost over $5 billion on its EV program in 2024, with the F-150 Lightning outsold by the Cybertruck.
- Farley warns that proposed tariffs could wipe out profits, affect U.S. jobs, and raise vehicle prices.

items.title: Fintech Ramp lands Eagles’ Saquon Barkley as investor and Super Bowl commercial star
items.author: Mary Ann Azevedo
items.summary:
- Saquon Barkley becomes an investor in fintech startup [Ramp](https://techcrunch.com/2024/04/17/ramp-raises-another-150-million-co-led-by-khosla-founders-fund-at-a-7-65b-valuation/) and stars in their Super Bowl commercial.
- Barkley initiated contact with Ramp after reading [Zero to One](https://www.amazon.com/Zero-One-Notes-Startups-Future/dp/0804139296) by Peter Thiel.
- The Super Bowl commercial features Barkley and was produced in just seven days.
- Ramp, founded in 2019, is valued at $7.65 billion and is known for corporate card and expense management services.
- This investment is Barkley’s largest private technology investment to date, alongside his previous investments in [Monad Labs](https://techcrunch.com/2023/02/14/monad-labs-raises-19m-to-grow-its-smart-contract-platform-and-improve-the-ethereum-space/) and others.
- The Super Bowl will take place on February 9, featuring the Eagles vs. the Kansas City Chiefs.

items.title: EU details which systems fall within AI Act’s scope
items.summary:
- The European Union has published guidance on defining AI systems under the AI Act.
- The risk-based framework regulating AI applications came into force last summer, with the first compliance deadline recently occurring.
- AI developers must determine if their software falls within the act’s scope to avoid fines of up to 7% of global annual turnover for breaches.
- The 13-page guidelines from the Commission are non-binding and subject to updates as the AI field evolves.
- The EU warns that there won't be exhaustive lists defining systems that fall within or outside the AI system definition.

items.title: Spyware maker Paragon terminates contract with Italian government: media reports
items.author: Lorenzo Franceschi-Bicchierai
items.summary:
- Paragon Solutions has terminated its contract with the Italian government after the company claimed the government violated agreed terms.
- This decision follows the disclosure by WhatsApp that Paragon's spyware was used to target journalists and activists.
- The Italian government denies any involvement with the spyware campaign and asserts that protected individuals were not targeted.
- Affected individuals include journalists critical of the government and activists opposing immigration policies.
- Paragon confirms it had to disconnect two Italian agencies from accessing its spyware product, Graphite.
- There are indications that victims of the spyware may be found in multiple European countries, not just Italy.

items.title: Mark Zuckerberg’s charity insists it’s not abandoning its DEI efforts
items.author: Not given
items.summary:
- Mark Zuckerberg’s charity, Chan Zuckerberg Initiative (CZI), reassured employees of its commitment to DEI despite Meta cutting its DEI programs.
- CZI’s HR leader Marck Gundacker emphasized that Meta and CZI operate independently, and Meta’s changes do not affect CZI.
- The organization, co-led by Zuckerberg and Priscilla Chan, has still made changes similar to Meta, such as layoffs and ending remote work policies.

items.title: GitHub Copilot brings mockups to life by generating code from images
items.author: Paul Sawers
items.summary:
- GitHub introduces Vision for Copilot, allowing users to generate code from images like screenshots and diagrams.
- New feature includes 'next edit suggestions' that predicts the next code edit based on recent edits.
- Copilot Edits graduates to general availability with new 'agent mode' for multi-file edits, aiming for more automation and intuitiveness in coding tasks.

items.title: RPLY is a new AI assistant that responds to missed texts
items.author: Molly Cantillon
items.summary:
- RPLY is a new Mac app aimed at helping users achieve 'inbox zero' on iMessage.
- The app uses AI to identify missed texts and suggests responses if messages go unreplied for over 24 hours.
- Created by Molly Cantillon, a Stanford dropout, RPLY is designed to reduce 'text debt' and improve genuine connections.
- It analyzes user text history to craft replies that match writing style and personality.
- RPLY includes features like filtering unanswered messages, displaying response statistics, and tracking inbox status.
- The app has attracted 1,000 paid users and targets professionals overwhelmed by messages.
- Privacy measures include a strict zero data retention policy and options for local processing on-device.
- Currently exclusive to macOS, with plans for potential future expansion to other platforms.

items.title: Keyboard maker suspends U.S. shipments over Trump tariffs on Chinese goods
items.summary:
- Qwertykeys suspends all U.S. product shipments due to new Trump administration tariffs.
- The decision follows a February 1 announcement of 10% tariffs on imported Chinese goods.
- All keyboards from China to the U.S. now subject to 45% tariffs at full value, replacing prior exemptions.
- DHL introduces a “tariff deposit” and a new $21 package processing fee affecting shipments.
- Qwertykeys is one of the first Chinese companies to halt shipments in response to these tariff increases, impacting smaller companies with tighter margins.

items.title: Flashes, a photo-sharing app for Bluesky, opens beta
items.author: Sarah Perez
items.summary:
- Flashes, an Instagram alternative on Bluesky, launched its beta for testers.
- The app supports photo posts of up to four images and videos of one minute.
- It filters Bluesky’s timeline to show posts with media, allowing users to switch between Bluesky feeds.
- Built by Sebastian Vogelsang, Flashes reuses code from his previous app, Skeets, which has over 30,000 users.
- As of now, Bluesky has nearly 31 million users and 1 billion posts.
- The beta faced technical issues but saw 3,500 sign-ups in the first hour.

items.title: Tinder revamps ‘Explore’ page to connect people with similar dating intentions
items.author: Lauren Forristal
items.summary:
- Tinder updated its Explore page with new categories: “Non-Monogamy,” “Serious Dater,” “Short-Term Fun,” “Long-Term Partner,” and “New Friends.”
- New categories will help users find matches based on dating intentions and compete with Bumble BFF for friendship connections.
- Update ahead of Valentine’s Day aims to attract users looking for dates for the occasion.

items.title: OpenAI co-founder John Schulman leaves Anthropic after just five months
items.summary:
- John Schulman, co-founder of OpenAI, has left AI startup Anthropic after five months.
- He joined Anthropic in August 2024 to focus on AI alignment and hands-on technical work.
- Schulman's departure was confirmed by multiple reports; Anthropic's chief science officer expressed support for his decision.

items.title: Superlogic raises $13.7M at a $200M valuation to help consumers use reward points toward cool ‘experiences’
items.author: Mary Ann Azevedo
items.summary:
- Superlogic raised $13.7 million at a $200 million valuation to enhance the value of rewards points.
- The platform allows consumers to redeem points for unique experiences instead of traditional options like hotel stays.
- Partners include American Express, Mastercard, and Visa, managing inventory and payments.

items.title: Spotify, Warner Music Group sign new deal to help deliver ‘further paid subscription tiers’
items.author: Aisha Malik
items.summary:
- Spotify and Warner Music Group have signed a multi-year agreement covering recorded music and music publishing.
- The deal aims to create new fan experiences, enhance the music catalog, and introduce further paid subscription tiers.
- Spotify CEO Daniel Ek announced a forthcoming 'superfan' premium tier with additional features for subscribers.
- This agreement follows a similar recent deal between Spotify and Universal Music Group.
- The new partnership allows Spotify to attract more subscribers and boost revenue.
- It includes a direct licensing model with Warner Chappell Music, increasing the music ecosystem's value for artists and fans.
- Financial terms of the deal were not disclosed.

items.title: Mistral releases its AI assistant on iOS and Android
items.author: Romain Dillet
items.summary:
- Mistral launches mobile app for its AI assistant Le Chat on [iOS](https://apps.apple.com/us/app/le-chat-by-mistral-ai/id6740410176) and [Android](https://play.google.com/store/apps/details?id=ai.mistral.chat).
- Le Chat features a chatbot interface supporting queries, with recent updates adding web search, image generation, and a deal with Agence France-Presse.
- A new Pro tier subscription is introduced for $14.99/month, offering access to the highest-performing model and higher usage limits.
- Mistral claims Le Chat can answer up to 1,000 words per second and generates better images than competitors due to advanced models.

items.title: a16z stands by decision to hire Daniel Penny
items.summary:
- Andreessen Horowitz (a16z) defends its decision to hire Daniel Penny following backlash.
- Penny was acquitted for choking a homeless man during a subway incident and has no previous investment experience.
- He will work with a16z's American Dynamism team focusing on government and defense, with plans for investment training.

items.title: OpenAI launches data residency in Europe
items.author: Kyle Wiggers
items.summary:
- OpenAI launched data residency in Europe, enabling compliance with local data sovereignty for its products.
- Customers can now process data locally with zero data retention on OpenAI's servers for eligible endpoints and services like ChatGPT Enterprise.
- European regulatory scrutiny has increased following previous allegations of noncompliance, with investigations initiated by several countries including Italy and Germany.

items.title: Intel Capital fuels TrueFoundry’s $19M funding to help boost AI deployments at scale
items.author: Jagmeet Singh
items.summary:
- TrueFoundry, founded by former Meta engineers, raised $19 million led by Intel Capital to enhance AI deployments.
- The startup's software, available as a platform-as-a-service, offers tools for auto-scaling, maintenance, and monitoring of AI systems.
- TrueFoundry's customers, including NVIDIA and Siemens Healthineers, benefit from expedited AI platform launches and significant cost reductions.

items.title: Fizz brings on TikTok alum to help build out its marketplace and recommendation engine
items.author: Aisha Malik
items.summary:
- Fizz has hired David Vasquez, former TikTok head of creator monetization, as its new head of product. 
- Vasquez will enhance Fizz's recommendation system and expand its marketplace to include in-app payments and brand partnerships. 
- The platform has seen a 245% increase in daily posts and a 61% rise in daily active users, attributed partly to uncertainty around TikTok's future in the U.S.

items.title: Lyft’s new AI customer assistant is powered by Anthropic’s Claude
items.author: Rebecca Bellan
items.summary:
- Lyft has partnered with Anthropic to create an AI assistant for customer service inquiries.
- The assistant aims to efficiently handle initial customer interactions for both riders and drivers, significantly reducing resolution time by 87%.
- This partnership follows Uber's similar collaboration with OpenAI, highlighting the competitive nature of AI integration in ride-hailing services.
- Lyft's AI assistant uses Anthropic’s Claude, a large language model, to provide human-like responses and handle common support issues.
- Lyft's broader collaboration includes training and tools integration for its engineers to utilize AI in various processes.

items.title: Pendulum’s AI-driven platform helps enterprises better predict supply and demand
items.author: Becca
items.summary:
- Pendulum offers an AI-driven platform to help enterprises optimize supply and demand based on fragmented data sources.
- Co-founder Benjamin Fels emphasizes the importance of precise supply demand management for sustainability and profit.
- The company rebranded from Macro-Eyes before a funding round of $22 million, focusing on expansion and product enhancement.
- Notable customers include Adore Me and the U.S. Department of Defense.
- Jean-François Gagné joins as chief strategy and product officer, adding expertise from his background at Element AI.
- The company stands out due to its algorithmic approach developed over a decade, addressing the fragility of supply chains exacerbated by the pandemic.

items.title: You can now use ChatGPT web search without logging in
items.summary:
* OpenAI now allows users to access ChatGPT web search without logging in.
* Previously, only premium subscribers could use real-time queries like sports scores and news.
* The login requirement for using ChatGPT Search has been removed for the web version, but the mobile app still requires login.

items.title: IMI becomes the latest British engineering firm to be hacked
items.summary:
- British engineering company IMI disclosed a cybersecurity incident on February 6, 2025.
- The firm reported unauthorized access to its systems and is engaging external cybersecurity experts.
- IMI is complying with regulatory obligations but has not confirmed if any data was exfiltrated.
- This follows a recent incident involving rival firm Smiths Group, which also faced unauthorized network access.

items.title: Shein gets more questions from EU about DSA compliance
items.author: Natasha Lomas
items.summary:
- The EU has sent a new request for information (RFI) to Shein regarding compliance with the Digital Services Act (DSA).
- The RFI seeks detailed information on risks related to illegal content, transparency of recommender systems, and data access for researchers.
- Shein must respond by February 27; failure to comply could lead to penalties up to 6% of global turnover.
- Concerns regarding consumer protection, public health, and product safety in low-cost ecommerce are increasing.
- The EU has not yet issued any DSA fines, despite multiple investigations and requests for information to platforms like Shein and AliExpress.

items.title: Could this startup’s compact nuclear reactors revolutionize cancer detection?
items.author: Mike Butcher
items.summary:
- Cancer rates are rising, increasing the demand for nuclear isotopes in medical settings.
- A startup, Astral Systems, is developing compact nuclear reactors using multistate fusion technology to enhance the supply of these isotopes.
- The company has secured over £4.5M in investment, aiming for better efficiency and lower costs than traditional reactors.
- Their approach is based on lattice confinement fusion, which achieves significantly higher fuel densities than conventional methods.
- Applications include safe hybrid nuclear energy, space exploration, and various industrial uses.
- Astral aims to decentralize production by placing reactors in hospitals or industrial sites, reducing reliance on centralized facilities.
